group.name: connection
group.description: Generic functions that affect the current connection.

func.name: connection.close
func.description:
connection.close() function writes the provided data directly back to the client. After the data has been sent, the connection is closed.

The optional second argument specifies whether ZXTM should continue to read in data from the client after sending this response, and wait for it to close the connection. If set to 0, ZXTM will close the connection immediately. If non-zero, ZXTM will wait and read any remaining data from the connection before closing it.

The default behaviour is to wait, because some client software will not read a response until it has sent its entire request.

func.name: connection.discard
func.description: connections.discard() immediately closes the current connection and stops processing rules. This is equivalent to the function call 'pool.use( "discard" )'.

func.name: connection.getBandwidthClass
func.description:
connection.getBandwidthClass() gets the current bandwidth class for the connection to the client. It will return an empty string if none is set.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by response.getBandwidthClass

func.name: connection.getData
func.description:
connection.getData() returns the first 'count' bytes of data provided by the client.

Warning: you can stall a connection by asking it to read more data than the remote client will provide. Combine this with connection.getDataLen() to reliably read data from a connection.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.get

func.name: connection.getDataLen
func.description:
connection.getDataLen() returns the amount of data already received from the client. This can be combined with connection.getData() to reliably read data from a connection without stalling if no data is available.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getLength

func.name: connection.getLine
func.description:
connection.getLine() returns a line of input data provided by the client. The line separator is '\n', and this is stripped off before returning the line. connection.getline() takes a single byte-count argument which informs ZXTM where to start scanning for a line; a value of '0' begins at the start, so returns the first line.

When connection.getline() returns, the variable $1 is updated to point to the start of the next line in the datastream.

You can iterate through the lines of input data by using $1 as the iterator variable.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getLine

func.name: connection.getLocalIP
func.description:
connection.getLocalIP() returns the IP address that the client connected to, i.e. the address local to this machine.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getLocalIP

func.name: connection.getLocalPort
func.description:
connection.getLocalPort returns the network port number that the client connected to. (e.g. port 80 is normal for a web server)

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getLocalPort

func.name: connection.getMemoryUsage
func.description: connection.getMemoryUsage() returns an estimate of the amount of memory currently in use for this connection, in bytes. Memory is primarily used for buffering data, and the memory usage can be tuned using the various buffer size settings.

func.name: connection.getNode
func.description: connection.getNode() returns the name of the back-end node that this connection is connected to. If a back-end node has not been chosen, which is normally the case in request rules, it returns the empty string.

func.name: connection.getPersistence
func.description: connection.getPersistence returns the name of the current Session Persistence class that will be used for this connection.

func.name: connection.getPool
func.description: connection.getPool() returns the name of the pool that this connection is connected to. If a pool has not been chosen, it returns the empty string.

func.name: connection.getRemoteIP
func.description:
connection.getRemoteIP returns the remote IP address of the client.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getRemoteIP

func.name: connection.getRemotePort
func.description:
connection.getRemotePort() returns the remote port of the client's connection.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.getRemotePort

func.name: connection.getServiceLevelClass
func.description: connection.getServiceLevelClass gets the current service level class for the connection. It will return an empty string if none is set.

func.name: connection.getVirtualServer
func.description: connection.getVirtualServer() returns the name of the Virtual Server that the rule is running under.

func.name: connection.setBandwidthClass
func.description:
connection.setBandwidthClass() sets the bandwidth class for the current connection to the client. Providing an empty class name removes the bandwidth class from the connection. It returns zero if an error occurs (for example, if the bandwidth class does not exist), and 1 otherwise.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by response.setBandwidthClass

func.name: connection.setData
func.description:
connection.setData() replaces the input data read from the client with the provided string.

This is a low-level routine that should be used with care. For protocols with their own higher-level protocol managers (e.g. http), use the higher level routines to alter the input data (e.g. http.setHeader() and http.setBody()).

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.set

func.name: connection.setIdempotent
func.description:
connection.setIdempotent() marks a request as resendable or non-resendable.

An idempotent request has no detrimental side effects, so it can safely be attempted multiple times. A non-idempotent request has a side effect - for example, it may update a database, or initiate a purchase.

By default, all non-HTTP requests are marked as idempotent. If a back-end node fails to generate a correct response when a request is initially forwarded to it, ZXTM will attempt to resend the request to another node.

connection.setIdempotent() can override this behaviour. If 'resend' is zero, this indicates that the request should only be attempted against one back-end node.

If 'resend' has a non-zero value, this indicates that if a request is made to a back-end node and a correct response is not received, ZXTM should retry the request against another back-end node.

Note that ZXTM cannot resend a request once has begun streaming data between the client and the node. Additionally, UDP connections cannot be marked as resendable (the UDP client application should handle failed UDP responses).

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by request.setIdempotent

func.name: connection.setPersistence
func.description: connection.setPersistence sets the Session Persistence class that will be used for the connection. If no parameter is given, it will remove any existing session persistence class.

func.name: connection.setPersistenceKey
func.description:
connection.setPersistenceKey sets the value of the Session Persistence key that is used by a Universal Session Persistence type class.

A Session Persistence class that uses Universal Session Persistence attempts to ensure that every connection that provides the same key is directed to the same back-end node.

This function has no effect if a different type of session persistence class is ultimately used.

func.name: connection.setPersistenceNode
func.description:
connection.setPersistenceNode sets the back-end node to be used by a NamedNode Persistence class.

A Session Persistence class that uses NamedNode Persistence will then ensure that this node will be used for the request. The node must be valid and exist in the Pool being used. If no port number is given, or if the port number is not valid, then if there is a node with a matching name, it will be used. For example, if the node 'web:80' is specified, but there is only a 'web:443', then that node will be used instead. This is to help share session persistence between different services on the same machine.

This function has no effect if a different type of session persistence class is ultimately used.

func.name: connection.setServiceLevelClass
func.description: connection.setServiceLevelClass sets the service level class for the current connection. It returns zero if an error occurs (for example, if the service level class does not exist), and 1 otherwise

func.name: connection.sleep
func.description: connection.sleep() pauses processing of the current connection for the specified number of milliseconds. This can be used to rate-limit particular clients; for example, those asking for particular files, or from particular locations, or using particular user-agents.

group.name: connection.data
group.description: Functions that allow you to store and retrieve data stored for the lifetime of the current connection.

func.name: connection.data.get
func.description: connection.data.get() returns the value that was previously stored with the given key using connection.data.set() in the current connection, or returns the empty string if no data was stored.

func.name: connection.data.set
func.description: connection.data.set() stores a value for this connection, associating it with the provided key. The value can be retrieved later when processing the same connection, using connection.data.get(). Once the connection finishes, the value cannot be retrieved.

group.name: counter
group.description: Functions for altering user defined counters.

func.name: counter.increment
func.description:
counter.increment increments the numbered counter. These counters are readable via SNMP, and can be graphed on the Current Activity page on the Administration Server.

By default, the counter is incremented by one, but you can also supply a number to increment the counter by.

group.name: data
group.description: Functions that allow you to store information shared between all rules.

func.name: data.get
func.description:
data.get() returns the value that was previously stored with the given key using data.set(), or returns the empty string if no data was stored.

Values stored in this way are persistent; a value stored in one rule can later be retrieved by a different rule handling a different connection. Thus, a rule can maintain persistent state across connections.

Note data is stored on a per process basis, so the data.get() function on multi-CPU machines may not return the expected value.

func.name: data.getMemoryUsage
func.description:
data.getMemoryUsage() returns an estimate of the amount of memory, in bytes, used by entries that have been stored by data.set().

This can be used to verify if a rule is storing excessive amounts of data, starving the host machine of memory.

func.name: data.remove
func.description:
data.remove() removes the value that was previously associated with the given key using data.set().

Note data is stored on a per process basis, so the data.remove() function will only remove the data in the current process.

func.name: data.reset
func.description:
data.reset() removes all mappings created by data.set().

Note data is stored on a per process basis, so the data.reset() function will only remove the data in the current process.

func.name: data.set
func.description:
data.set() stores a value persistently, associating it with the provided key. The value can be retrieved later using data.get(), even from a different rule or connection.

The value will be stored as a string, implicit conversion of floating point numbers to strings can cause some precision loss. You can convert a floating point number into a string with no precision loss using 'string.sprintf( "%f", $val )'.

Note data is stored on a per process basis, so a subsequent data.get() call for a different connection may not retrieve the previously stored data.

group.name: http
group.description: HTTP protocol-specific functions.

func.name: http.addHeader
func.description: http.addHeader() modifies the current HTTP request, adding an HTTP header with the supplied value. If the header already exists, then this value will be appended to the existing value. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: http.addResponseHeader
func.description: http.addResponseHeader() adds an HTTP header to the HTTP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then this value will be appended to the existing value. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: http.changeSite
func.description: http.changeSite() can be used to redirect users to a new website. It is a more sophisticated version of http.redirect(), that will preserve the original path that the request asked for. For instance, if the original request was for 'http://www.example.com/image/image.jpg', then http.changeSite( "example.co.uk" ) would redirect the user to 'http://example.co.uk/image/image.jpg' The redirection will preserve the original path (and any query string) of the request, together with the port number and protocol. If you wish to force any of these details, then you can specify them as part of the supplied host name. e.g. http.changeSite( "https://www.example.com" ) will always send people to a SSL-encrypted site. You can also add on a prefix to the path of the URL, e.g. http.changeSite( "www.example.com/oldsite" ) would redirect a request for 'http://www.example.com/missing/page.html' to 'http://www.example.com/oldsite/missing/page.html'. If the original request matches the supplied redirection, then http.changeSite() will take no action and let the request continue. This ensures that no 'redirection loops' occur.

func.name: http.cookie
func.description:
http.cookie() returns the value of the named cookie.

Function is deprecated.
Replaced by http.getCookie

func.name: http.doesFormParamExist
func.description:
http.doesFormParamExist() checks whether a form parameter is present, either in the URL query string, or if not found and the request is a POST, from the POST body data. It returns 1 if the parameter is present, and 0 if not.

This is useful when there are form parameters with no value, e.g a query string like 'foo=bar&stuff&x=y' - the 'stuff' parameter has no value, but is present.

func.name: http.getBody
func.description:
http.getBody() returns the body data of the request.

If the optional 'count' parameter is supplied, http.getBody() will only read and return this number of bytes. If count is 0, http.getBody() returns the entire request.

If the request has no body, then this returns an empty string. This function is not useable in response rules, as the body data of the request will no longer be accessible.

func.name: http.getCookie
func.description:
http.getCookie() returns the value of the named cookie in the incoming HTTP request.

http.getCookie is a helper method that makes it easier to parse the HTTP Cookie header and extract the values of that particular cookie, rather than using http.getHeader() directly.

An HTTP 'Cookie' header can have multiple values, such as

  Cookie: user-id=Joe; user-type=gold

http.getCookie( ... ) will retrieve the 'Cookie' header line and parse it, returning the value of the cookie. If the cookie does not exist, http.getCookie() will return the empty string.

func.name: http.getFormParam
func.description:
http.getFormParam() returns the %-decoded form parameter from the URL query string, or if not found and the request is a POST, from the POST body data.

If the parameter is provided twice, only the first will be returned, unless the optional Separator is provided, in which case all matches will be returned, separated with this string.

func.name: http.getHeader
func.description: http.getHeader() returns the value of a named HTTP header in the HTTP request, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: http.getHeaderNames
func.description:
http.getHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the request.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: http.getHostHeader
func.description: http.getHostHeader() returns the HTTP Host header. This value is lowercased and has the port removed. Any trailing full stop is also removed. For example if the Host header is 'www.Zeus.com:80' then http.getHostHeader() returns 'www.zeus.com'.

func.name: http.getMethod
func.description: http.getMethod() returns the HTTP method that was used to make the request, such as GET or POST.

func.name: http.getMultipartAttachment
func.description: http.getMultipartAttachment() gets the specified data out of a multipart encoded HTTP request. The data contained in the part is returned on success, or "" if it doesn't exist for that part. $1 contains the Content Type of the part, and $2 contains the complete headers for that part.

func.name: http.getPath
func.description: http.getPath() returns the %-decoded path in the HTTP request URL, stripping the query string if one was provided. If there is a leading scheme and authority prefix, this is removed as well, so a raw url of 'http://www.example.com/content?page=44' will be returned as '/content'.

func.name: http.getQueryString
func.description: http.getQueryString() returns the %-decoded query string in the URL, or the empty string if no query string was provided.

func.name: http.getRawQueryString
func.description: http.getRawQueryString() returns the raw query string in the URL, or the empty string if no query string was provided.

func.name: http.getRawURL
func.description:
http.getRawURL() returns the raw URL data provided by the client in the first line of the HTTP request, after the method and before the HTTP version specifier.

The raw URL data includes both the path and query string if supplied and is not decoded. It may also contain the protocol and hostname if the client sent them. It could contain %-escaped characters that can be used to disguise the contents of the URL. Use http.getPath() or http.getQueryString() to return the %-decoded version of the path or query string.

This function could return raw urls of various forms including:

  • http://www.example.com/file.html
  • /file.html
  • /path/../file.html
  • /file.html?querystring
  • /file.html?qs%encoded

You can use http.normalisePath() on the path component to remove any '/../' or '/./' references.

In general it is better to use http.getPath() and http.getQueryString() to avoid the need to process the raw url.

func.name: http.getRequest
func.description: http.getRequest() returns the full HTTP request and headers, but does not include any body data.

func.name: http.getResponse
func.description: http.getResponse() returns the beginning of the HTTP response (the status line and the headers), up to but not including the empty line that separates the headers from the body. The returned string does not include any body data.

func.name: http.getResponseBody
func.description:
http.getResponseBody() returns the body of the HTTP response.

If the optional 'count' parameter is provided, http.getResponseBody() will read and return the first 'count' bytes of the response. If count is 0, http.getResponseBody() will return the entire response.

func.name: http.getResponseCode
func.description: http.getResponseCode() returns the status code from the first line of the HTTP response.

func.name: http.getResponseCookie
func.description:
http.getResponseCookie() returns the value of the named cookie in the HTTP response.

http.getResponseCookie is a helper method to make it easier to parse the HTTP Set-Cookie header and extract the values of that particular cookie, rather than using http.getResponseHeader() directly.

If the cookie does not exist, http.getResponseCookie() will return the empty string.

This function should be called in a response rule; it has no effect in a request rule.

func.name: http.getResponseHeader
func.description: http.getResponseHeader() returns the value of a named HTTP header in the HTTP response, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: http.getResponseHeaderNames
func.description:
http.getResponseHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the response.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: http.getResponseVersion
func.description: http.getResponseVersion() returns the version of the HTTP protocol being used. It returns the version string in the first line of the HTTP response, such as 'HTTP/1.1'. It will return the empty string in the case of HTTP/0.9 response.

func.name: http.getVersion
func.description: http.getVersion() returns the version of the HTTP protocol being used. It returns the version string in the first line of the HTTP request, such as 'HTTP/1.1'. It will return the empty string in the case of HTTP/0.9, which does not have a version specifier in the request.

func.name: http.headerExists
func.description:
http.headerExists() determines if a named header exists or not. It is similar to http.getHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: http.normalisePath
func.description:
http.normalisePath() flattens a decoded URL path, converting '//' to '/', '/./' to '/', and flattening '/a/../' to '/'. It returns the flattened path string.

If the file system path is invalid, this function returns the empty string. Invalid paths include those that contain disallowed characters like '\0', invalid hex-escapes, or that use '../' sequences to reference a location outside the local root.

This function should be used on the retrieved URL before attempting path matching for access control.

func.name: http.redirect
func.description: http.redirect() sends back a HTTP 302 redirect response, which will send a web browser to a different URL. This is equivalent to http.sendResponse( "302 Moved Temporarily", "text/html", "", "Location: " . $url );

func.name: http.removeCookie
func.description:
http.removeCookie() removes the named cookie from the incoming HTTP request.

http.removeCookie is a helper method that makes it easier to parse the HTTP Cookie header and remove a particular cookie, rather than using http.getHeader() and http.setHeader() directly.

func.name: http.removeHeader
func.description: http.removeHeader() removes a named header if it exists in the request. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: http.removeResponseCookie
func.description:
http.removeResponseCookie() removes the named cookie from the HTTP response.

http.removeResponseCookie is a helper method, to avoid using http.removeResponseHeader() directly. It operates correctly when there are multiple Set-Cookie headers in the response.

This function should be called in a response rule; it has no effect in a request rule.

func.name: http.removeResponseHeader
func.description: http.removeResponseHeader() removes the named HTTP header from the HTTP response. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: http.responseHeaderExists
func.description:
http.responseHeaderExists() determines if a named header exists in the HTTP response. It is similar to http.getResponseHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: http.scrubRequestHeaders
func.description:
http.scrubRequestHeaders() limits the allowed HTTP request headers to a known set. The allowed headers can either be passed in as a list or space separated in a single argument.

Care should be taken when using this function to ensure that the headers that are required for connection handling are let through. At the very least, the following should be allowed:

Connection, Content-Length, Transfer-Encoding, Content-Type, Host
For a complete list of HTTP headers, refer to RFC2616. Protocols that extend HTTP, such as WebDAV, use other headers.

func.name: http.scrubResponseHeaders
func.description:
http.scrubResponseHeaders() limits the allowed HTTP response headers to a known set. The allowed headers can either be passed in as a list or space separated in a single argument.

Care should be taken when using this function to ensure that the headers that are required for connection handling are let through. At the very least, the following should be allowed:

Connection, Content-Length, Transfer-Encoding, Location
For a complete list of HTTP headers, refer to RFC2616. Protocols that extend HTTP, such as WebDAV, use other headers.

func.name: http.sendResponse
func.description: http.sendResponse() sends back an HTTP response to the client instead of balancing the request via a pool onto a node. It generates a correct HTTP response from the response code, content type, body data and headers supplied. Multiple headers should be separated with \r\n.

func.name: http.setBody
func.description:
http.setBody() sets the request body for this HTTP request to the supplied string, replacing any request body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the request to the length of the new body data.

func.name: http.setCookie
func.description:
http.setCookie() sets the value of the named cookie in the incoming HTTP request.

http.setCookie is a helper method that makes it easier to parse the HTTP Cookie header and set the value of a particular cookie, rather than using http.getHeader() and http.setHeader() directly.

An HTTP 'Cookie' header can have multiple values, such as

  Cookie: user-id=Joe; user-type=gold

func.name: http.setHeader
func.description:
http.setHeader() sets the value of the named HTTP header, replacing any existing value if the header already exists.

Note that this function should not be used with the Connection header, i.e. setHeader("Connection", value) since it may not give the expected results.

The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: http.setIdempotent
func.description:
http.setIdempotent() marks a request as resendable or non-resendable.

An idempotent request has no detrimental side effects, so it can safely be submitted multiple times. A simple page retrieval is generally idempotent. A non-idempotent request has a side effect - for example, it may update a database, or initiate a purchase. The HTTP/1.1 specification regards all GET, HEAD, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS and TRACE requests as idempotent.

ZXTM tags these requests as 'resendable'; if the request is submitted to a back-end node and a correct response is not received, ZXTM will resubmit the request to another back-end node. All other requests, such as POST requests are not resent if a back-end node fails to generate a correct response.

http.setIdempotent() can override this behaviour. If 'resend' has a non-zero value, this indicates that if the request is submitted to a back-end node and a correct response is not received, ZXTM should resubmit the request to another back-end node.

If 'resend' is zero, this indicates that the request should only be attempted against one back-end node.

Note that ZXTM cannot resend a request if it has begun streaming data from the client to the node before it detects the failure. To avoid this, you can read the entire request within the TrafficScript rule, so that it is buffered in its entirety internally in the TrafficManager.

func.name: http.setMethod
func.description: http.setMethod() sets the HTTP method to use when forwarding the request via a pool to a node.

func.name: http.setPath
func.description: http.setPath() replaces the Path portion of the request URL with the supplied value. If the replacement value contains a '?', this function will also replace the query string; otherwise, any query string is preserved. Any control characters are %-encoded in the replacement value.

func.name: http.setQueryString
func.description: http.setQueryString() replaces the query-string portion of the request URL with the supplied replacement. Any control characters in the replacement are %-encoded.

func.name: http.setRawQueryString
func.description: http.setRawQueryString() replaces the query-string portion of the request URL with the supplied replacement. Unlike http.setQueryString control characters are not encoded.

func.name: http.setResponseBody
func.description:
http.setResponseBody() sets the response body for this HTTP response to the supplied string, replacing any response body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the response to the length of the new body data. In addition the 'Content-Encoding' header is removed as we only ever set body data which is not encoded or compressed. If the server is still sending the original response body when this function is called, the connection to the server will be harmlessly dropped.

The optional transfer-encoding parameter indicates the encoding of the body data (for example, 'chunked').

func.name: http.setResponseCode
func.description: http.setResponseCode() sets the status code and message in the first line of the HTTP response.

func.name: http.setResponseCookie
func.description:
http.setResponseCookie() sets the value of the named cookie in the HTTP response.

http.setResponseCookie is a helper method to make it easier to parse the HTTP Set-Cookie header and set the value of a particular cookie, rather than using http.getResponseHeader() and http.setResponseHeader() directly.

The options are a semi-colon separated list of cookie options, such as 'domain', 'path', 'exipres' and 'secure'. These options are defined in the Netscape Cookie specification, at http://wp.netscape.com/newsref/std/cookie_spec.html

If the named cookie already exists, this function replaces its value.

If the named cookie exists and no 'options' are provided, the current options for the named cookie are preserved.

This function may be called from a request rule or a response rule.

func.name: http.setResponseHeader
func.description:
http.setResponseHeader() sets a HTTP header in the HTTP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then it will be replaced with this new value.

Note that this function should not be used with the Connection header, i.e. setResponseHeader("Connection", value) since it may not give the expected results.

The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

group.name: http.cache
group.description: Functions affecting the HTTP cache.

func.name: http.cache.disable
func.description: Invoking http.cache.disable() in a response rule prevents the response from being cached.

func.name: http.cache.enable
func.description: http.cache.enable() performs the opposite function to http.cache.disable(), and re-enables the default caching behaviour when the dynamic caching option in the virtual server is enabled.

func.name: http.cache.setkey
func.description: http.cache.setkey() allows multiple variants of the same URL to be considered distinct objects, even if the standard 'Vary' RFC semantics would consider the pages identical. Cached objects will be stored with this key, and subsequent requests for the same URL will only match if the same key is provided. An example use is to provided different cached content based on a portion of the User-Agent field of the request.

group.name: http.compress
group.description: Functions affecting the HTTP compression of this connection.

func.name: http.compress.disable
func.description: http.compress.disable() stops an HTTP response from being compressed. This function overrides the Virtual Server Content Compression settings, so this is useful for stopping particular MIME types for certain browsers from being compressed.

func.name: http.compress.enable
func.description: http.compress.enable() allows an individual HTTP response to be compressed. If this function is called for an HTTP response, then the Virtual Server settings for Content Compression are ignored, and the response will be compressed assuming that the client supports compression.

group.name: http.request
group.description: Functions that allow you to send HTTP requests within TrafficScript rules.

func.name: http.request.get
func.description:
http.request.get() issues an HTTP request for a remote web page and returns the body of the page requested. $1 is set to the HTTP response code (e.g. 200 for OK), or is 0 if there was an error. $2 is set to the Content-Type of the response. $3 is set to the content-headers of the response, in the format: [ ]*. $4 is set to the first line of the HTTP response. The entire original response may be reconstructed as $4." ".$3. ".$body, where $body is the result of http.request.get.

HTTPS pages can be requested by using the https:// prefix for the url.

A timeout parameter can be given (in seconds). If the request does not complete in this time, then an error will be given instead.

func.name: http.request.head
func.description:
http.request.head() issues an HTTP HEAD request for a remote web page. $1 is set to the HTTP response code (e.g. 200 for OK), or is 0 if there was an error. $2 is set to the Content-Type of the response. $3 is set to the content-headers of the response, in the format: [ ]*. $4 is set to the first line of the HTTP response. The entire original response may be reconstructed as $4." ".$3. ".$body, where $body is the result of http.request.get.

HTTPS pages can be requested by using the https:// prefix for the url.

A timeout parameter can be given (in seconds). If the request does not complete in this time, then an error will be given instead.

func.name: http.request.post
func.description:
http.request.post() issues an HTTP POST request for a remote web page, and returns the body of the page requested. $1 is set to the HTTP response code (e.g. 200 for OK), or is 0 if there was an error. $2 is set to the Content-Type of the response. $3 is set to the content-headers of the response, in the format: [ ]*. $4 is set to the first line of the HTTP response. The entire original response may be reconstructed as $4." ".$3. ".$body, where $body is the result of http.request.post.

HTTPS pages can be requested by using the https:// prefix for the url.

A timeout parameter can be given (in seconds). If the request does not complete in this time, then an error will be given instead.

group.name: java
group.description: Functions relating to Java Extensions.

func.name: java.run
func.description: java.run runs a named Java Extension. The Java Extension class name must be given, and extra options can also be supplied to the Extensions. (These are supplied as the 'args' attribute in the Java Extension API).

group.name: lang
group.description: Standard functions, mostly for converting data types.

func.name: lang.chr
func.description: lang.chr() converts its parameter to the corresponding ASCII character. chr() may be used an a shorthand alias for lang.chr().

func.name: lang.max
func.description: lang.max() returns the maximum value of the two parameters provided. If both parameters are strings, it uses a string comparison; otherwise, the parameters are promoted to integers or doubles and compared. max() may be used as a shorthand for lang.max().

func.name: lang.min
func.description: lang.min() returns the minimum value of the two parameters provided. If both parameters are strings, it uses a string comparison; otherwise, the parameters are promoted to integers or doubles and compared. min() may be used as a shorthand for lang.min().

func.name: lang.ord
func.description: lang.ord() converts its parameter, an ascii character, to an integer. ord() may be used as a shorthand alias for lang.ord().

func.name: lang.toDouble
func.description: lang.toDouble() returns the double (floating point) value of its parameter, using the TrafficScript type-casting rules.

func.name: lang.toInt
func.description: lang.toInt() returns the integer value of its parameter, using the TrafficScript type-casting rules.

func.name: lang.toString
func.description: lang.toString() returns the string value of its parameter, using the TrafficScript type-casting rules.

func.name: lang.tochar
func.description: This function is an alias for lang.chr.

group.name: log
group.description: Functions for writing to the event log.

func.name: log.error
func.description:
log.error() writes an error message to ZXTM's log file at ZEUSHOME/zxtm/log/errors:

  [21/Jan/2004:10:42:50 +0000] SERIOUS:Insert coffee to continue

func.name: log.info
func.description:
log.info() writes an informational message to ZXTM's log file at ZEUSHOME/zxtm/log/errors:

  [21/Jan/2004:10:42:50 +0000] INFO:Everything is OK

func.name: log.warn
func.description:
log.warn() writes a warning message to ZXTM's log file at ZEUSHOME/zxtm/log/errors:

  [21/Jan/2004:10:42:52 +0000] WARN:There may be trouble ahead

group.name: math
group.description: Mathematical functions for manipulating numbers.

func.name: math.acos
func.description: math.acos() calculates the arc cosine of x and returns an angle in radians in the range 0 to pi.

func.name: math.asin
func.description: math.asin() calculates the arc sine of x and returns an angle in radians in the range -pi/2 to pi/2.

func.name: math.atan
func.description: math.atan() calculates the arc tangent of x and returns an angle in radians in the range -pi/2 to pi/2.

func.name: math.ceil
func.description: math.ceil() returns the smallest integer greater than or equal to its parameter.

func.name: math.cos
func.description: math.cos() interprets its parameter as an angle in radians and returns its cosine.

func.name: math.exp
func.description: math.exp() calculates e raised to the power of its parameter and returns the result.

func.name: math.fabs
func.description: math.fabs() interprets its parameter as a floating point number and returns its absolute value.

func.name: math.floor
func.description: math.floor() returns the largest integer not greater than its parameter.

func.name: math.ln
func.description: math.ln() returns the natural logarithm of its parameter.

func.name: math.log
func.description: math.log() returns the base10 logarithm of its parameter.

func.name: math.pow
func.description: math.pow() raises its first parameter to the power of its second parameter and returns the result.

func.name: math.random
func.description: math.random() returns a pseudorandom integer greater than or equal to zero, and less than its parameter.

func.name: math.rint
func.description: math.rint() rounds its parameter by returning the integer closest to its value.

func.name: math.sin
func.description: math.sin() interprets its parameter as an angle in radians and returns its sine.

func.name: math.sqrt
func.description: math.sqrt() returns the square root of its parameter.

func.name: math.tan
func.description: math.tan() interprets its parameter as an angle in radians and returns its tangent.

group.name: net.dns
group.description: DNS lookup functions.

func.name: net.dns.resolveHost
func.description: net.dns.resolveHost() resolves a hostname into an IPv4 address, using the DNS name servers configured on the local system. If the lookup fails, an empty string is returned.

func.name: net.dns.resolveHost6
func.description: net.dns.resolveHost6() resolves a hostname into an IPv6 address, using the DNS name servers configured on the local system. If the lookup fails, an empty string is returned.

func.name: net.dns.resolveIP
func.description:
net.dns.resolveIP() resolves an IP address to a hostname, using the DNS name servers configured on the local system.

It returns a hostname, or the IP address if the address cannot be resolved. An empty string is returned if the parameter is not a valid IP address.

group.name: pool
group.description: Functions that allow you to look up and alter which pool the current request will be assigned to.

func.name: pool.activenodes
func.description: pool.activeNodes() returns the number of nodes that are alive in the named pool. This will not include any nodes that have been marked as 'draining'.

func.name: pool.select
func.description:
pool.select() selects a pool to load-balance this connection with. By default the pool name should be a literal string, however, if you enable the "trafficscript!variable_pool_use" global setting variables can be used too. Please refer to section 5.5 of the ZXTM TrafficScript Overview and Reference for more information about this setting. ZXTM will continue to process any request rules.

If the pool named does not exist, ZXTM will log a warning message.

Optionally, a specific machine can be specified that will be used to forward the request on to. This machine does not have to be in the pool selected, or in fact in any pool. In this mode, the selected pool is used only for its configuration settings (e.g. timeout values, SSL encryption options, etc.)

func.name: pool.use
func.description:
pool.use() selects a pool to load-balance this connection with, and stops processing any more rules. It must only be used in request rules.

By default the pool name should be a literal string, however, if you enable the "trafficscript!variable_pool_use" global setting, variables can be used too. Please refer to section 5.5 of the ZXTM TrafficScript Overview and Reference for more information about this setting.

If the pool named does not exist, ZXTM will log a warning message and use the default pool configured for the virtual server.

Optionally, a specific machine can be specified that will be used to forward the request on to. This machine does not have to be in the pool selected, or in fact in any pool. In this mode, the selected pool is used only for its configuration settings (e.g. timeout values, SSL encryption options, etc.)

group.name: rate
group.description: Functions that allow you to monitor and assign rate shaping classes.

func.name: rate.getbacklog
func.description: rate.getBacklog return the number of connections that are currently waiting to be released by the supplied rate class.

func.name: rate.use
func.description: rate.use immediately queues a connection using the named rate class. The connection and the current TrafficScript rule is stalled until the rate class releases it, according to the rate limits defined in the class. When the connection is released, the rate.use() function returns and the TrafficScript rule continues to execute. If rate.use is called with the optional 'context' value, it uses a new rate class which inherits all of the rate settings from the named rate class. All connections called with the same 'context' value use the same new rate class. This allows you to shape connections based on arbitary data, such as a user name or source IP address, shaping connections from different users or source IPs independently. If the connection has passed through the class successfully then the value 1 is returned. If the connection times out while it is queued, then the TrafficScript rule is abandoned. If the connection could not be queued because an invalid rate class name was provided, rate.use() returns 0.

group.name: request
group.description: Functions that allow you to access information about and modify the current request.

func.name: request.avoidNode
func.description:
request.avoidNode() can be used to indicate that ZXTM should avoid using the named node if at all possible, if it retries the request.

When retrying a request, ZXTM will not use any nodes that have been named by request.avoidNode() unless session persistence mandates it, or unless there are no other nodes available.

func.name: request.endsAt
func.description:
request.endsAt() marks the end of the current request. Any more data read in from the network is not handled until ZXTM begins to handle the next request.

This function is useful to synchronise requests and responses. An example of its use would be for a line-oriented protocol such as POP3, where you wish to process each command.

It returns the entire request.

This function allows you to program layer-7 intelligence to correctly parse and manage generic TCP protocols.

func.name: request.endsWith
func.description:
request.endsWith() marks the end of the current request. Any more data read in from the network is not handled until ZXTM begins to handle the next request.

This function is useful to synchronise requests and responses. An example of its use would be for a line-oriented protocol such as POP3, where you wish to process each command.

It returns the entire request.

This function allows you to program layer-7 intelligence to correctly parse and manage generic TCP protocols.

func.name: request.get
func.description:
request.get() returns the first 'count' bytes of data provided by the client in the current request. If no count parameter is provided, then ZXTM immediately returns all available data.

Warning: you can stall a connection by asking it to read more data than the remote client will provide. Combine this with request.getLength() or request.getLine() to reliably read data from a connection. For HTTP, you are advised to use the HTTP specific functions like http.getBody() to read the request.

func.name: request.getBandwidthClass
func.description: request.getBandwidthClass() gets the current bandwidth class for the connection to the backend node. It will return an empty string if none is set.

func.name: request.getDestIP
func.description: request.getDestIP returns the original IP address that the client attempted to connect to. This will be the same as request.getLocalIP() unless the connection was redirected via firewall rules (e.g. using iptables on Linux)

func.name: request.getDestPort
func.description: request.getDestIP returns the original network port number that the client attempted to connect to. This will be the same as request.getLocalPort() unless the connection was redirected via firewall rules (e.g. using iptables on Linux)

func.name: request.getLength
func.description: request.getLength() returns the amount of data already received from the client. This can be combined with request.get() to reliably read data from a connection without stalling if no data is available.

func.name: request.getLine
func.description:
request.getLine() returns a line of request data provided by the client. The line is terminated by the supplied regular expression, or by '\n'. If 'offset' is provided, request.getLine() returns the data from that offset to the terminating expression. The terminating expression is included in the returned string.

When request.getline() returns, the variable $1 is updated to point to the start of the next line in the datastream.

You can iterate through the lines of request data by using $1 as the iterator variable.

func.name: request.getLocalIP
func.description: request.getLocalIP returns the IP address that the client connected to, i.e. the address local to this machine.

func.name: request.getLocalPort
func.description: request.getLocalPort returns the network port number that the client connected to. (e.g. port 80 is normal for a web server)

func.name: request.getRemoteIP
func.description: request.getRemoteIP returns the remote IP address of the client.

func.name: request.getRemotePort
func.description: request.getRemotePort returns the remote network port of the client's connection.

func.name: request.getRetries
func.description: request.getRetries() returns the number of times that this request has been explicitly retried by request.retry().

func.name: request.getToS
func.description: request.getToS returns the Type of Service (ToS) of traffic going to the server. The return value is either "LOWDELAY", "THROUGHPUT", "RELIABILITY" or "NONE".

func.name: request.getfd
func.description: request.getfd() returns the number of the file descriptor used for communication with the client. It returns -1 on failure.

func.name: request.isResendable
func.description:
request.isResendable() is used in a response rule to test if it is possible to resend a request to a different node. It is only possible to resend a request if the entire request has been buffered up in ZXTM, for example, by explicitly reading it in a request rule.

If the request was streamed through to the client, for example, as a large HTTP POST, it will not have been buffered and therefore cannot be resent.

Note that request.isResendable detects if it is possible to resend a request; request.setIdempotent can be used to tell ZXTM not to automatically resend a request if it fails.

func.name: request.retry
func.description:
request.retry() is used in a response rule to retry the request against the selected pool. Load-balancing and session persistence decisions are recalculated, and the request is resubmitted - possibly to the same node as previous, although request.avoidNode() can prevent this.

If request.retry() is called, any request rules are not run again. When a new response is collected after request.retry(), the response rules are run again.

The response rule can modify the request in before resubmitting it.

It's only generally possible to resend a request if the entire request was read before the request rules completed. Otherwise, request data will have been streamed to the server and not cached. Use request.isResendable() to test this speculatively.

request.getRetries() returns the number of times this request has been tried already.

On success, request.retry() does not return, but the response rules will be run again on the new response. On failure, request.retry() returns 0. request.retry() will do nothing if used in a request rule.

func.name: request.sendResponse
func.description:
request.sendResponse() writes the provided data directly back to the client.

Any data that has been read is discarded, and nothing is forwarded to the back-end node. Once the response data has been written, control returns to the next request.

func.name: request.set
func.description:
request.set() replaces the input data read from the client with the provided string.

This is a low-level routine that should be used with care. For protocols with their own higher-level protocol managers (e.g. http), use the higher level routines to alter the input data (e.g. http.setHeader() and http.setBody()).

func.name: request.setBandwidthClass
func.description: request.setBandwidthClass() sets the bandwidth class for the current connection to the backend node. Providing an empty class name removes the bandwidth class from the connection. It returns zero if an error occurs (for example, if the bandwidth class does not exist), and 1 otherwise.

func.name: request.setIdempotent
func.description:
request.setIdempotent() marks a request as resendable or non-resendable.

An idempotent request has no detrimental side effects, so it can safely be attempted multiple times. A non-idempotent request has a side effect - for example, it may update a database, or initiate a purchase.

By default, all non-HTTP requests are marked as idempotent. If a back-end node fails to generate a correct response when a request is initially forwarded to it, ZXTM will attempt to resend the request to another node.

request.setIdempotent() can override this behaviour. If 'resend' is zero, this indicates that the request should only be attempted against one back-end node.

If 'resend' has a non-zero value, this indicates that if a request is made to a back-end node and a correct response is not received, ZXTM should retry the request against another back-end node.

Note that ZXTM cannot resend a request once it has begun streaming data between the client and the node. Additionally, UDP connections cannot be marked as resendable (the UDP client application should handle failed UDP responses).

func.name: request.setRemoteIP
func.description: request.setRemoteIP sets the remote IP address of the client. This function should be used with care, as it will alter what is logged in request logs and the address seen by a back-end node in 'transparent' mode. 0 is returned if the IP address is invalid, and 1 otherwise.

func.name: request.setToS
func.description: request.setToS sets the Type of Service (ToS) of traffic going to the server to either "LOWDELAY", "THROUGHPUT", "RELIABILITY" or "NONE".

func.name: request.skip
func.description:
request.skip() removes the specified number of bytes from the start of the request provided by the client. This can be used in combination with request.get() and request.getLine() to stream data from a client, or to alter a request before passing it on to a server.

Successive calls to this function will remove further data.

group.name: resource
group.description: Functions that allow you to access files uploaded to the 'Extra Files' section of the traffic manager.

func.name: resource.exists
func.description: resource.exists() checks whether or not the named file exists in ZEUSHOME/zxtm/conf/extra/. If it exists 1 is returned, 0 otherwise.

func.name: resource.get
func.description: resource.get() returns the contents of a named file stored in the ZEUSHOME/zxtm/conf/extra/ directory. If the file doesn't exist, then an empty string is returned. Note that subdirectories of conf/extra are not supported.

func.name: resource.getMD5
func.description: resource.getMD5() returns the MD5 of the current contents of the file in ZEUSHOME/zxtm/conf/extra/. If the file doesn't exist, an empty string is returned.

func.name: resource.getMTime
func.description: resource.getMTime() returns the last time that the named file in ZEUSHOME/zxtm/conf/extra/ was modified, in seconds since the epoch (i.e. UNIX time). If the file doesn't exist, 0 is returned.

group.name: response
group.description: Functions that allow you to access information about and modify the current response.

func.name: response.append
func.description:
response.append() appends the provided string to the response data

This is a low-level routine that should be used with care. For protocols with their own higher-level protocol managers (e.g. http), use the higher level routines to alter the input data (e.g. http.setHeader() and http.setBody()).

func.name: response.close
func.description:
response.close() immediately closes the connection to the back-end node. Any response data that has already been read from the server will be forwarded to the client, but no more response data will be read.

ZXTM will reconnect to a back-end node when it next needs to forward request data to it; the back-end node is specified by either calling pool.use() or pool.select() in a request rule, or by the default pool.

func.name: response.flush
func.description:
response.flush() transfers the first count bytes of the response back to the client. These bytes are removed from the underlying response buffer. If count is not specified, all current response data is flushed.

This function is useful in generic client- and server-first protocols, to synchronise responses with the next request. This may be necessary if ZXTM is likely to respond directly to some requests, and the back-end node responds to others.

func.name: response.get
func.description:
response.get() returns the first 'count' bytes of data provided by the server in the current response. If you do not supply a count parameter, then the entire response will be read in.

Warning: you can stall a connection by asking it to read more data than the remote client will provide. Combine this with response.getLength() or response.getLine() to reliably read data from a connection.

func.name: response.getBandwidthClass
func.description: response.getBandwidthClass() gets the current bandwidth class for the connection to the client. It will return an empty string if none is set.

func.name: response.getLength
func.description: response.getLength() returns the amount of data already received from the server. This can be combined with response.get() to reliably read data from a connection without stalling if no data is available.

func.name: response.getLine
func.description:
response.getLine() returns a line of response data provided by the server. The line is terminated by the supplied regular expression, or by '\n'. If 'offset' is provided, response.getLine() returns the data from that offset to the terminating expression.

When response.getline() returns, the variable $1 is updated to point to the start of the next line in the datastream.

You can iterate through the lines of response data by using $1 as the iterator variable.

func.name: response.getLocalIP
func.description: response.getLocalIP returns the local IP address of the connection to the node in use, i.e. an IP address on the local machine that ZXTM connected from. It returns the empty string if no connection exists.

func.name: response.getLocalPort
func.description: response.getLocalPort returns the local port of the connection to the node in use, i.e. the port number on the local machine that ZXTM connected from. It returns 0 if there is no current connection to a node.

func.name: response.getRemoteIP
func.description: response.getRemoteIP returns the remote IP address of the node used. If there is no current connection, it will return an empty string.

func.name: response.getRemotePort
func.description: response.getRemotePort returns the network port number that ZXTM connected to a node. (e.g. port 80 is normal for a web server). If there is no current connection, it will return 0.

func.name: response.getToS
func.description: response.getToS returns the Type of Service (ToS) of traffic going to the client. The return value is either "LOWDELAY", "THROUGHPUT", "RELIABILITY" or "NONE".

func.name: response.getfd
func.description: response.getfd() returns the number of the file descriptor used for communication with the back-end node. It returns -1 on failure.

func.name: response.set
func.description:
response.set() sets the server response to the provided string

This is a low-level routine that should be used with care. For protocols with their own higher-level protocol managers (e.g. http), use the higher level routines to alter the input data (e.g. http.setHeader() and http.setBody()).

func.name: response.setBandwidthClass
func.description: response.setBandwidthClass() sets the bandwidth class for the current connection to the client. Providing an empty class name removes the bandwidth class from the connection. It returns zero if an error occurs (for example, if the bandwidth class does not exist), and 1 otherwise.

func.name: response.setToS
func.description: response.setTos sets the Type of Service (ToS) of traffic going to the client to either "LOWDELAY", "THROUGHPUT", "RELIABILITY" or "NONE".

group.name: rtsp
group.description: RTSP protocol-specific functions.

func.name: rtsp.addRequestHeader
func.description: rtsp.addRequestHeader() modifies the current RTSP request, adding an RTSP header with the supplied value. If the header already exists, then this value will be appended to the existing value. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: rtsp.addResponseHeader
func.description: rtsp.addResponseHeader() adds an RTSP header to the RTSP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then this value will be appended to the existing value. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: rtsp.getMethod
func.description: rtsp.getMethod() returns the RTSP method that was used to make the request, such as SETUP or PLAY.

func.name: rtsp.getPath
func.description: rtsp.getPath() returns the %-decoded path in the RTSP request URL

func.name: rtsp.getRawURL
func.description: rtsp.getRawURL() returns the raw URL data provided by the client in the first line of the RTSP request, after the method and before the RTSP version specifier.

func.name: rtsp.getRequest
func.description: rtsp.getRequest() returns the full RTSP request and headers, but does not include any body data.

func.name: rtsp.getRequestBody
func.description:
rtsp.getRequestBody() returns the body data of the request.

If the optional 'count' parameter is supplied, rtsp.getRequestBody() will only read and return this number of bytes. If count is 0, rtsp.getRequestBody() returns the entire request.

If the request has no body, then this returns an empty string. This function is not useable in response rules, as the body data of the request will no longer be accessible.

func.name: rtsp.getRequestHeader
func.description: rtsp.getRequestHeader() returns the value of a named RTSP header in the RTSP request, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: rtsp.getRequestHeaderNames
func.description:
rtsp.getRequestHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the request.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: rtsp.getResponse
func.description: rtsp.getResponse() returns the full RTSP response and headers, but does not include any body data.

func.name: rtsp.getResponseBody
func.description:
rtsp.getResponseBody() returns the body of the RTSP response. This could be an SDP response.

If the optional 'count' parameter is provided, rtsp.getResponseBody() will read and return the first 'count' bytes of the response. If count is 0, rtsp.getResponseBody() will return the entire response.

func.name: rtsp.getResponseCode
func.description: rtsp.getResponseCode() returns the status code from the first line of the RTSP response.

func.name: rtsp.getResponseHeader
func.description: rtsp.getResponseHeader() returns the value of a named RTSP header in the RTSP response, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: rtsp.getResponseHeaderNames
func.description:
rtsp.getResponseHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the response.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: rtsp.getVersion
func.description: rtsp.getVersion() returns the version of the RTSP protocol being used. It returns the version string in the RTSP/version specifier in the first line of the RTSP request, such as 'RTSP/1.0'.

func.name: rtsp.redirect
func.description: rtsp.redirect( path ) sends back an RTSP 302 redirect response, which will send the client to a different URL. This is equivalent to rtsp.sendResponse( "302 Moved Temporarily", "", "Location: " . $url );

func.name: rtsp.removeRequestHeader
func.description: rtsp.removeRequestHeader() removes a named header if it exists in the request. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: rtsp.removeResponseHeader
func.description: rtsp.removeResponseHeader() removes the named RTSP header from the RTSP response. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: rtsp.requestHeaderExists
func.description:
rtsp.requestHeaderExists() determines if a named header exists or not. It is similar to rtsp.getRequestHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: rtsp.responseHeaderExists
func.description:
rtsp.responseHeaderExists() determines if a named header exists in the RTSP response. It is similar to rtsp.getResponseHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: rtsp.sendResponse
func.description: rtsp.sendResponse() sends back an RTSP response to the client instead of balancing the request via a pool onto a node. It generates a correct RTSP response from the response code, body data and headers supplied. Multiple headers should be separated with \r\n.

func.name: rtsp.setMethod
func.description: rtsp.setMethod() sets the RTSP method to use when forwarding the request via a pool to a node.

func.name: rtsp.setPath
func.description: rtsp.setPath() replaces the Path portion of the request URL with the supplied value.

func.name: rtsp.setRequestBody
func.description:
rtsp.setRequestBody() sets the request body for this RTSP request to the supplied string, replacing any request body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the request to the length of the new body data.

func.name: rtsp.setRequestHeader
func.description:
rtsp.setRequestHeader() sets the value of the named RTSP header, replacing any existing value if the header already exists.

Note that this function should not be used with the Connection header, i.e. setRequestHeader("Connection", value) since it may not give the expected results.

The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: rtsp.setResponseBody
func.description:
rtsp.setResponseBody() sets the response body for this RTSP response to the supplied string, replacing any response body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the response to the length of the new body data. If the server is still sending the original response body when this function is called, the connection to the server will be harmlessly dropped.

func.name: rtsp.setResponseCode
func.description: rtsp.setResponseCode() sets the status code and message in the first line of the RTSP response.

func.name: rtsp.setResponseHeader
func.description:
rtsp.setResponseHeader() sets a RTSP header in the RTSP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then it will be replaced with this new value.

Note that this function should not be used with the Connection header, i.e. setResponseHeader("Connection", value) since it may not give the expected results.

The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

group.name: rule
group.description: Functions relating to this rule.

func.name: rule.getName
func.description: rule.getName returns the name of the currently executing rule.

func.name: rule.getState
func.description: returns the state of the currently executing rule, either REQUEST or RESPONSE.

group.name: sip
group.description: SIP protocol-specific functions.

func.name: sip.addRequestHeader
func.description: sip.addRequestHeader() modifies the current SIP request, adding a SIP header with the supplied value. If the header already exists, then this value will be appended to the existing value. If at_top is set then the value will be prepended to the header. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: sip.addResponseHeader
func.description: sip.addResponseHeader() adds a header to the SIP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then this value will be appended to the existing value. If at_top is set then the value will be prepended to the existing value. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

func.name: sip.getMethod
func.description: sip.getMethod() returns the SIP method that was used to make the request, such as INVITE or REGISTER.

func.name: sip.getRequest
func.description: sip.getRequest() returns the full SIP request and headers, but does not include any body data.

func.name: sip.getRequestBody
func.description: sip.getRequestBody() returns the data contained in the body of the request.

func.name: sip.getRequestHeader
func.description: sip.getRequestHeader() returns the value of a named SIP header in the SIP request, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: sip.getRequestHeaderNames
func.description:
sip.getRequestHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the request.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: sip.getRequestURI
func.description: sip.getRequestURI() returns the target of the SIP request.

func.name: sip.getResponse
func.description: sip.getRequest() returns the full SIP response and headers, but does not include any body data.

func.name: sip.getResponseBody
func.description: sip.getResponseBody() returns the session description of the SIP response.

func.name: sip.getResponseCode
func.description: sip.getResponseCode() returns the status code from the first line of the SIP response.

func.name: sip.getResponseHeader
func.description: sip.getResponseHeader() returns the value of a named SIP header in the SIP response, or the empty string if the header does not exist or has an empty value. The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

func.name: sip.getResponseHeaderNames
func.description:
sip.getResponseHeaderNames() returns a list of all the headers that are present in the response.

The headers are returned as a single string, separated by spaces.

func.name: sip.getVersion
func.description: sip.getVersion() returns the version of the SIP protocol being used. It returns the version string in the SIP/version specifier in the first line of the SIP request, such as 'SIP/2.0'.

func.name: sip.redirect
func.description: sip.redirect( contact ) sends back a 302 Moved Temporarily response. This response instructs the client to retry the request at the new address(es) given in the 'contact' parameter. This is equivalent to sip.sendResponse( "302", "Moved Temporarily", "Contact: " . $uri, "" );

func.name: sip.removeRequestHeader
func.description: sip.removeRequestHeader() removes a named header if it exists in the request. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: sip.removeResponseHeader
func.description: sip.removeResponseHeader() removes the named SIP header from the SIP response. The header name is automatically translated to the correct case.

func.name: sip.requestHeaderExists
func.description:
sip.requestHeaderExists() determines if a named header exists or not. It is similar to sip.getRequestHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: sip.responseHeaderExists
func.description:
sip.responseHeaderExists() determines if a named header exists in the SIP response. It is similar to sip.getResponseHeader(), but makes it possible to distinguish between a header not being present and a header having no value.

The header name is automatically translated into the proper case for the lookup.

It returns 1 if the header exists, and 0 if it does not.

func.name: sip.sendResponse
func.description: sip.sendresponse() sends back a SIP response to the client instead of balancing the request via a pool onto a node. The Statue-Line of the response has the form: SIP/2.0 code reason Via, Record-Route, From, To, CSeq, Call-ID and Content-Length headers are automatically added to the response. Any headers supplied in the headers parameter will also be added to the response. Multiple headers must be separated by \r\n. Any body data specified is appended to the response.

func.name: sip.setMethod
func.description: sip.setMethod() sets the SIP method to use when forwarding the request via a pool to a node.

func.name: sip.setRequestBody
func.description:
sip.setRequestBody() sets the request body for this SIP request to the supplied string, replacing any request body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the request to the length of the new body data.

func.name: sip.setRequestHeader
func.description: sip.setRequestHeader() sets the value of the named SIP header, replacing any existing value if the header already exists.

func.name: sip.setRequestURI
func.description: sip.setRequestURI() sets the target of the SIP request.

func.name: sip.setResponseBody
func.description:
sip.setResponseBody() sets the response body for this SIP response to the supplied string, replacing any response body already present.

This also updates the 'Content-Length' header in the response to the length of the new body data. If the server is still sending the original response body when this function is called, the connection to the server will be harmlessly dropped.

The optional transfer-encoding parameter indicates the encoding of the body data (for example, 'chunked').

func.name: sip.setResponseCode
func.description: sip.setResponseCode() sets the status code and message in the first line of the SIP response.

func.name: sip.setResponseHeader
func.description:
sip.setResponseHeader() sets a header in the SIP response that will be sent back to the client. If the header already exists in the response, then it will be replaced with this new value.

The header name is automatically translated to the correct case before it is added.

group.name: slm
group.description: Functions for accessing information from the Service Level Monitoring class assigned to this connection.

func.name: slm.conforming
func.description: slm.conforming() returns the current percentage of requests that are meeting the Service Level Monitoring objectives. If no class name is provided, it will use the SLM class currently associated with this connection; if no SLM class is associated with this connection, it returns 100.

func.name: slm.isOK
func.description: slm.isOK() returns whether a particular Service Level Monitoring class is meeting its objectives. If no class name is provided, it will use the SLM class currently associated with this connection; if no SLM class is associated with the connection, it returns 1. This function is a convenience shorthand for 'slm.conforming() > slm.threshold()'.

func.name: slm.threshold
func.description: slm.threshold() returns the percentage of connections that need to meet the Service Level Monitoring alert threshold for the SLM class to be considered OK. If no class name is provided, it will use the SLM class currently associated with this connection; if no SLM class is associated with the connection, it returns 0.

group.name: ssl
group.description: Functions relating to the encryption applied to the current connection.

func.name: ssl.clientCert
func.description: ssl.clientCert() returns the PEM encoded client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertAlgorithm
func.description: If the connection is SSL-encrypted and the client has supplied a valid certificate, ssl.clientCertAlgorithm() returns either 'rsaEncryption', 'md2withRSAEncryption', 'md5withRSAEncryption', 'sha1withRSAEncryption' or 'RSA', depending on the certificate's encryption and hash algorithms. Otherwise, it returns the empty string.

func.name: ssl.clientCertEndDate
func.description:
If the connection is SSL-encrypted and the client has supplied a valid certificate, ssl.clientCertEndDate() returns the date when the certificate is no longer valid. The date is an integer, representing seconds since the epoch.

Otherwise, this function returns 0.

func.name: ssl.clientCertHash
func.description: ssl.clientCertHash() returns a hex-encoded MD5 hash of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertIssuer
func.description: ssl.clientCertIssuer() returns a string representing the issuer of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertPublicKey
func.description: ssl.clientCertPublicKey() returns a string representation of the public key of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertSerial
func.description: This function returns the serial of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertStartDate
func.description:
If the connection is SSL-encrypted and the client has supplied a valid certificate, ssl.clientCertStartDate() returns the date when the certificate became valid. The date is an integer, representing seconds since the epoch.

Otherwise, this function returns 0.

func.name: ssl.clientCertStatus
func.description: ssl.clientCertStatus() returns 'OK' if the client certificate is valid, or 'NoClientCert' if it was missing or not valid. It returns the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted.

func.name: ssl.clientCertSubject
func.description: ssl.clientCertSubject() returns a string representing the subject of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCertVersion
func.description: ssl.clientCertVersion() returns "1", "2" or "3" denoting the version of the client certificate, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted or if a certificate was not supplied.

func.name: ssl.clientCipher
func.description:
ssl.clientCipher() returns the cipher used by the client to SSL-encrypt the connection. It returns an empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted.

The string returned contains the cipher algorithm, SSL version and effective cipher strength, such as:

  SSL_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA, version=SSLv3, bits=128

func.name: ssl.isSSL
func.description: ssl.isSSL() returns 1 if this connection from the remote client was SSL encrypted and ZXTM has decrypted the traffic. Otherwise, it returns 0.

func.name: ssl.sslSessionID
func.description: ssl.sslSessionID() returns the session-id of the current SSL connection, or the empty string if the connection was not SSL-encrypted.

group.name: string
group.description: Functions for manipulating and encoding strings.

func.name: string.BERToInt
func.description: string.BERToInt() converts a BER compressed integer into an integer.

func.name: string.append
func.description: string.append() takes any number of parameters. It interprets each as a string and returns the result of concatenating them all together.

func.name: string.base64decode
func.description:
string.base64decode() decodes a base64-encoded string and returns the result.

Base64 encoding is used for MIME-encoded messages, and in the HTTP Basic Authorization header.

func.name: string.base64encode
func.description:
string.base64encode() returns the base64-encoded version of the provided string. This converts each group of three characters into a 4-character string containing just [A-Za-z0-9+/], and '=' for padding.

Base64 encoding is used for MIME-encoded messages, and in the HTTP Basic Authorization header.

func.name: string.bytesToDotted
func.description: string.bytesToDotted() converts a network ordered byte string into an IP address.

func.name: string.bytesToInt
